Budget Table Overview
Show me that modern shizz

<<Budget>>

This is the budget table, basically a digital cash envelope system! But this ain't your Grandma's budgeting...

<<Budget>>

The Category column houses the names of each spending category.

<<Budget>>

The Budgeted column is where you'll be budgeting your dollars. This shows you what you have set aside each month for each category.

<<Budget>>

Next up is the Spent column. This shows you what you've actually spent out of the budgeted dollars in the current month for each category.
Got it!

<<Budget>>

The last column is Balance. This shows you what you still have available to spend. If it's negative and red, you've overspent in this category. If the amount is black, that's what you have left available to spend.

<<Budget>>

If you don't cover red overspending, you either risk over-drafting your checking account or adding debt to your credit card. More on this later!

<<Budget>>

Take a look at the three dots next to the word Category. This gives you visual options. You can collapse and expand category groups. You can also show and hide Hidden categories.

<<Budget>>

When you hover over a row a small down arrow will pop up to the right of the title. Here you can also rename or delete a Category or Group.
I added a category

<<Budget>>

Now, please add a category to the Usual Expenses Group. Click the arrow to the right of Usual Expenses, and "Add category." Choose a regular monthly bill you pay, such as Rent or Mortgage.

If you have a balance on the card, you will see a red number in the Balance column for the card. 

But even if you could pay it off in full today, you haven't assigned money to that category yet. 

You have debt and MyBudgetCoach wants you to address it.
Let's do this! 💪🏼
I'm ready to be awesome with money!
Most of us were not taught in school or by our parents how to manage money, but my belief is that everyone can become awesome with money.
Whether you're new to budgeting or just looking for a new method, I’m grateful you’re here and taking a hands-on approach to becoming a money master!
Let's Roll Anyway

The funding plan is going to cover your necessary expenses, as well as the things you enjoy spending money on.
For me that’s Travel 🌎, Self-care 💅🏼, and my favorite hobby – Roller Skating. (Can you believe my computer didn't have an emoji of a roller skate!?)
Oof! Been there!

You bet! Zero-based budgeting is so powerful because we operate with only the money we have on hand and can quickly make spending decisions based on our values and our plan – not just the number in our bank account.
We'll go through the steps together

Here's our gameplan:

1) Add Accounts
2) Record Transactions
3) Trusting your numbers
4) Budget Tour & Setup
5) Budgeting Skills

I find it incredibly helpful to have a clear objective in mind when learning anything.

You can also organize categories and groups so they make the most sense to you.
Progress over perfection

<<Budget>>

Don't worry about getting all your categories perfect. As transactions start to come in you'll know when you'll need to add a category you may have forgotten about.
Why do you recommend these Groups?

<<Budget>>

Here are some Groups I recommend adding into your budget if you don't have them already:

Monthly Expenses
Variable Expenses
Annual Expenses
Fun
Savings Goals

These are only suggestions, you don't need to add them.
Got it!

<<Budget>>

Monthly Expenses are for those expenses that happen every month and are generally the same amount each month. Things like your car payment, phone bill, etc.

<<Budget>>

Variable Expenses are things that are going to happen but you don't know exactly when and how much they will be. They vary.

<<Budget>>

We know these expenses WILL happen; we just don't know when.

<<Budget>>

I recommend keeping things like Medical, Car Repairs, Vet Visits, and things of that nature in a group so that you can start to save small amounts for them over time.
I'd love to not feel the pain of a car repair

<<Budget>>

Then, when they inevitably happen, you'll be way ahead on being able to pay for them. 

This can help you break reliance on credit cards or keep you from draining your emergency fund.

More on this later...

<<Budget>>

The Annual Expenses are pretty self explanatory. These expenses happen once a year. 
Think Car Registration, Annual Subscriptions, Memberships, etc.
I like fun

<<Budget>>

Fun is for those things that you enjoy, but aren't as crucial to fund as some of your Monthly and Variable Expenses.

<<Budget>>

Maybe there's a bill that can wait until the next paycheck, or a "want" that can't be funded right now.

<<Budget>>

In this case, you can move money from one category to another.

If there's nothing left in "To Budget" you'll  need to take from other categories to fund a category that's more urgent.
Moving money

<<Budget>>

Instead of waiting for bills to come in, you'll think ahead to what expenses are coming and the money will sit in its category ready for the bill.

<<Budget>>

<<Budget>>

Can't take from nothing. Makes sense!

It becomes a way of living.

Why it's important

A crucial part of this process is entering transactions as they happen. 
There are several ways to make sure your transactions are being entered in a timely way.

Let's head back to Accounts.
What's another way?

<<Accounts>>

There are several ways to keep your transactions up to date. One is manually entering transactions as they happen. 

Hint: If you're using the manual entry method make sure any transactions that include a tip are entered as the purchase amount + tip.
Let's go over ways to do that

<<Accounts>>

For you to be able to rely on your Budget and the funds you have allocated to each category, you need to make sure your transactions are up to date, as they affect how much is available in the Budget.

<<Accounts>>

You can keep your receipts and enter transactions all at once, once a day or every couple days. Don't let this go for too long. Set an alarm or reminder in your calendar to stay on top of these.

<<Accounts>>

No worries! You've got options! 
One option is to download a QIF, OFX, QFX, or CSV file of transactions from within your bank account.

<<Accounts>>

And if adding transactions manually sounds like hell to you, I've got you. I'll introduce other options. It's important that you do know HOW to manually add transactions though.

<<Accounts>>

The process can be slightly different depending on the bank, but there is an option for this within your online banking platform.

<<Accounts>>

If you don't see this option when you log into your bank account and need help finding this file, google "downloading transactions from ____ bank"
But what if I despise the thought of entering everything manually?

<<Accounts>>

Have you heard of "habit stacking?" This can also be useful to stay accountable to yourself.

<<Accounts>>

Basically, you choose something you do every day without thinking about it, like drinking a morning cup of coffee --  or whatever happens after the coffee 😳 -- and pair this new habit with that.

This is just AN example.

When you do the automatic task in combination with the new habit it is easier for your brain to adjust to the new habit.
And if I don't want to do that either?

<<Accounts>>

Then when you download the file, you'll come into MyBudgetCoach and use the "Import" option inside of the account you're working on.

(It's located just under the balance.)

<<Accounts>>

There's a small fee for this of $1.50/mo or $15/year paid directly to SimpleFIN. It's totally optional.
Good to know

<<Accounts>>

Within SimpleFIN there are several security measures in place to protect users. The purpose of this software is to pull data. The software does not alter the data or your bank accounts.

<<Accounts>>

No worries, then you can "Link" your accounts using a Third Party Software called SimpleFIN. This will automatically import transactions within a day or two.

Why we reconcile

<<Accounts>>

Something else you'll want to check frequently is that the balance in your account in MyBudgetCoach matches the account balance you have in your bank account.
This process is called Reconciling.

<<Accounts>>

2) Click on the three dots and choose "Reconcile"

<<Accounts>>

3) If the number highlighted in the box matches what your bank says your balance is, great! You can leave the amount in there and select "Reconcile" then "Done Reconciling."
I want to trust my budget

<<Accounts>>

We reconcile because if MyBudgetCoach doesn't agree with your bank accounts, the numbers in your Budget cannot be relied on with 100% certainty.
Ok, now onto the DIY steps

<<Accounts>>

It might not be off by a lot, but we want to frequently check this so we are operating with the correct information. The smaller budget you are working with, the more important this will be.

<<Accounts>>

You will Reconcile one account at a time.

<<Accounts>>

To do a Reconciliation Transaction you'll click on the three dots again, and select "Reconcile."
You'll enter in your CORRECT bank account balance and click "Reconcile" again.

How often should I reconcile?

<<Accounts>>

Don't give up. You got this.

If you want a personal call to walkthrough this process please set up a Zoom call with me so you can get comfortable with the steps.
So how do I Reconcile?

<<Accounts>>

Because once again, if you can't trust your numbers on the Accounts side, you can't fully trust what's in your Budget.

This is because the dollars in your Budget are based on the total of the accounts in MyBudgetCoach.

<<Accounts>>

My recommendation is at least once a week. Some people love to reconcile every day, while other budgeters who are on top of their game may only do it every few weeks.

<<Accounts>>

I HIGHLY recommend setting a reminder for yourself to reconcile once a week.
I'm going to get so fast at this! 🏃🏼‍♀️💨

<<Accounts>>

If this feeling like a lot right now, that's just because you haven't done it yet. 

Once you've done it a few times it will be a breeze!

<<Accounts>>

If your account is off, the first thing to do is enter any information that may be missing from the transaction register. Compare the transactions in your bank account to the transactions in MyBudgetCoach.

<<Accounts>>

If you're up to date on entering transactions, discrepancies will happen less and less over time.

<<Accounts>>

The locks are a visual representation that if you have a discrepancy when you reconcile next time, you don't need to compare transactions any further than these locks.

<<Accounts>>

Make sure all posted transactions have been cleared with the ✅ next to that transaction.
Again, that green check mark represents that the transaction is no longer "pending" in your bank account.

<<Accounts>>

Add or adjust any transactions as necessary in MyBudgetCoach so they agree with the transactions in your bank account.

<<Accounts>>

Some things to look out for are:
  

➡ Duplicate transactions

➡ Transactions that were labeled incorrectly as a Deposit or Payment when it should have been the opposite

➡ Tips/Gratuities that were not calculated into the total

Then you'll click the option to "Create Reconciliation Transaction."

<<Accounts>>

When you're reconciled you'll notice all those ✅ next to transactions turn into green locks 🔒

You don't want to be constantly playing catchup with overspending as that puts you back into reactive money management, but don't be too hard on yourself if it happens from time to time.

"Off Budget" accounts are totally optional to add if you like a lot of data or want to track net worth in "Reports". These will NOT affect the budgeting dollars in the budget and are for your information only.

Budget Table Overview

<<Budget>>

This is the budget table, basically a digital cash envelope system! You create categories relevant to your life and budget dollars accordingly.

<<Budget>>

The Category column houses the names of each category. We'll get customizing these in a bit.

<<Budget>>

The Budgeted column is where you'll be budgeting your dollars. This shows you what you have allocated each month for the categories.

<<Budget>>

Next up is the Spent column. This shows you what you've actually spent out of the budgeted dollars.

<<Budget>>

The last column is Balance. This shows you what you have available to spend. If it's negative and red, you've overspent in this category. If the amount is black, that's what you have available.

<<Budget>>

If you don't cover this overspending, you either risk over-drafting your checking account or adding debt to your credit card. More on this later!

<<Budget>>

Take a look at these three dots. This gives you visual options. You can collapse and expand category groups. You can also show and hide Hidden categories.

<<Budget>>

When you hover over a row, an arrow appears. You have options to add a category in this group, hide it, rename it or delete it.

<<Budget>>

Now, add a category to this group. Click that arrow again, and add a category. Choose a regular monthly bill you pay, such as your rent or mortgage.

<<Budget>>

Trusting Your Numbers

One of the complexities for users with a zero-based budgeting software is the due diligence to ensure the account balances in MyBudgetCoach match the account balances in the financial institution. 

A difficult part of having the accounts match is ensuring the starting balance set by the user at the time the accounts are added are accurate. For checking accounts, some banks include pending transactions in the Current Balance. If the starting balance includes pending transactions, then when the transactions are added, they will be double counted. For credit cards, the Current Balance doesn't include pending transactions, so this is not an issue. 

Coach can consider consulting Coach Trainers to add a flow for verifying starting balance.
Coach should consider adding a flow for walking a user through how to link accounts with SimpleFin. Consult with Coach Trainers if interested in sample flow.

People who have Credit Card balances in excess of their available dollars in their checking account will have a negative amount To Budgeted. This is an important step for the user, but can be handled in a various number of ways. Consider the main steps the user needs to complete, and then determine as the coach if you want to add more detail for any of those steps:

1) Adding the Credit Card Category Group
2) Add a Category for each Credit Card
3) Changing the category on the account side of the Credit Card starting balance to the newly created Category
4) Rollover overspending if not going to pay off balance

This will give the user back their dollars in their checking account in the To Budgeted.

Budget Setup

You as the Coach can do as much or as little as you would like for the user. For example, if you just want to add a handful of categories, or walk them through how to edit and add themselves, that is fine. Alternatively, you could have the system build an entire budget with defined groups, and categories, so when they select the button before the template is built, it automatically updates.
